label: real
header: "It’s a crime against all of Russia"
article:
The whistleblower Edward Snowden has lived in exile in Moscow for years. He is nevertheless demanding that the people behind the attack on Alexei Navalny be brought to justice. A conversation about fear for your own life and surveillance in times of the coronavirus
Lesen Sie diesen Text auf Deutsch
ZEIT ONLINE: The US-President Donald Trump said publicly
that he considers to pardon you. What was your first reaction, when you heard
the news?
Snowden: I was surprised to hear the
President talking about it so openly at a press conference. And immediately, I
asked all my friends: Has anybody heard about this? But it was really…
ZEIT: …out of the blue?
Snowden: I think it was a surprise to
everyone, but everybody was at the same time encouraged by it – not so much,
because they think it is actually likely to happen. But it’s a continued
normalization of the conversation about this. Realistically, I think we are
still early in the phase of that. For example, the President recently pardoned
someone whose been dead for 150 years and that’s normally the way it works with
American pardons for figures that are controversial. Once you’re dead and
everybody involved in this is dead, they think about it. 
ZEIT ONLINE: You are still alive and Barack Obama already considered to
pardon you before.
Snowden: This is a conversation that was
happening under the Obama administration, but my understanding - of course, no
one knows but Obama what happened – was that, because he was personally
involved in the wrongdoing that had been exposed, it was a bridge too far. It
is also important to understand that I didn’t asked for pardon from Obama just
like I haven’t asked for pardon from Trump today.
ZEIT: But why did Donald Trump bring up
your case now?
Snowden: Because he was asked by a
journalist at the press conference, twice in the same week. Since then, we have
seen Mike Pompeo and basically everybody at the CIA hiding all pens in the
White House to make sure nothing gets signed. 
ZEIT: Trump called you a "traitor" before
and a "spy that should be executed". Why do you think he changed his mind?
Snowden: That does not particularly surprise
me. Trump changed his positions on a lot of things in the past. The reality is,
whether it’s Trump or someone else, seeing an American president think hard
about the powers that state security organizations have, it’s a positive thing.
He said he’s heard people talking about it because I’ve been treated unfairly.
And I think, the one thing that we can all agree, regardless of whether the people
like me or don’t like me, is that my case was certainly handled exceptionally
and exceptional treatment is typically unfair treatment.
ZEIT: Do you have any sleepless nights
because of the current discussion?
Snowden (laughs). Not at all. It’s more like something you say on
Twitter: Wow, that’s a thing! I’ll believe it when I see it. 
ZEIT: For the course of privacy and
digital rights, who would be the better next President for the United States?
Snowden: That’s a tough question. We haven’t
seen any willingness on the side of either party. We have seen these topics
endlessly politicized for gain, but I don’t think, we have a genuine movement
for reform here. 
ZEIT: You have been away from the United States for seven years. When you left, Obama was still president, now your
country seems completely changed and divided. How do you regard it from a
distance?
Snowden: The funny thing is when I talk to
people who are in the United States and haven’t left, they say it seems and
feel like a different country. When you look at what’s happened since 2013 in
the US, we are living at a moment of transformation. Technology has been the
catalyzing force of this transformation in a way, we haven’t yet fully
apprehended. 
ZEIT: What do you mean exactly?
Snowden: The Internet has changed it all. What
we are seeing is a deconstruction of the news system. Competing for attention
fairly is obviously not the best way to win influence and so we see the
creation of these Facebook-type themes where we simply spy on everyone, if we
see what they click on, if we see what they like, if we see what moves them. We
can begin to change that. We can provide different ads to different people. We
can try to shape their behavior to what is ultimately subterfuge. Then of course,
this gives rise to disinformation campaigns that we see everywhere. We are
still in the early phase of the disruptive phase of that, where the
institutions of today don’t yet have a way to handle that and they are worried
about unrest and dissatisfaction. And those who are dissatisfied can associate
and discover those of like-mind. They can shape their dissatisfaction, develop
their arguments for good and bad.
ZEIT: You mean the rise of conspiracy
theories which is a good keyword to move to the Corona virus. For someone like
you who dedicated his life to fight against mass surveillance, the measures
against the pandemic like contact tracing must be your worst nightmare become
true. 
Snowden: People look at me and think that I
am categorically against all surveillance. They think of me as some kind of
bomb-tossing radical. But the reality is that I am not. I am  against mass surveillance. I was never
against targeted surveillance. I believe that intelligence services can do
something good, if they have a proper sense of mission, if they are focused on
people who are legitimate dangers to the public. The problem is when they start
looking at what they can’t do, what their raw capability, their raw budget,
their raw technology could enable them to start doing. This is kind of what has
happened with Corona virus tracking. The idea of contact tracing in some
settings does have value and the fact that everybody has their own tracking
device in their pocket. But Scientists and people in government who have
sympathies to the scale for the problem are saying: Well, what can we do with
technology? We can track everybody in the country now. We can just get this
stuff directly from telecommunications providers to some degree of detail. But
maybe they’re all going to mandate people to install this kind of app that
turns every commission on the phone on, uses every sensor… 
ZEIT: Which sounds like an architecture
of oppression.
Snowden: Exactly. And this is the great danger.
When we look at the case of Corona virus tracking, unless the virus has
basically been eradicated in the country, these apps don’t have a lot of public
health value. Contact tracing is useful when you
have ten infections or a hundred and you are trying to get where exactly this
individual went and try to track them down. But once you have a thousand
people, ten thousand people who have been infected, contact tracing stops being
useful because you no longer have the capability to intervene. The reality is
that these Covid tracking systems are well-intended, but not effective. What we
have done is, we have provided all the surveillance with none of the benefit.
ZEIT: Would you voluntarily use a Corona
warning app?
Snowden: It depends on how the app is designed.
Can we entirely see its code? Can we control how it is being used? Is its
manner of collecting information and sharing it entirely voluntary? One of the
early proposals for those apps was: turn everything on and share every bit of
information immediately with the government. This is a top-down authoritarian
model. Better is a model where everything is anonymized, with random numbers
which are not associated to names but shared with a register. 
ZEIT: Which is the way the App is working
in Germany. And would you use such an App?
Snowden: Right now, I would not use it,
because none of these things are useful unless we have a testing and treatment
infrastructure in place, and we don’t. What is better than Corona virus tracking
is a vaccine. I would take a vaccine.
ZEIT ONLINE: But aren’t most people
in countries like Germany voluntarily giving up their personal data because of
the virus? Is this an invitation to abuse?
Snowden: In my country, we have political saying: Never
let a crisis go to waste. This was the story of 9/11.
ZEIT ONLINE: By saying "my country", you still mean the
United States?
Snowden: Yes, it’s the United States, I am not a
citizen of Russia. When we look at the Patriot Act, the law invented shortly
after 9/11, we must say that it is in many cases the origin of the US mass
surveillance system. We were doing things like radio frequency monitoring
before, but the Patriot Act brought surveillance to the Internet, into the
lives of ordinary people who do ordinary things. The Patriot Act was a law that
had been written long before. That had been sitting on the shelf at the
Department of Justice and at the White House for years and years on the wish
list, but they knew there was no way it could ever pass, because it was so antithetical
to American values. And then, 9/11 happened.
ZEIT ONLINE: And you believe that we’re witnessing something
similar again right now?
Snowden: We know that people lose their ability to
reason when they are afraid. And if you remember that moment of peak Corona
virus panic in March and April, people were thinking, the world was going to
collapse, toilet paper was selling out everywhere, people were buying anything
they could, because they were ready for Doomsday. Politicians are not immune to
these moments. The idea in a republic, in a representative form of government
is we elect the people who are the best and brightest among us. But can you
really say, when you turn on the television and you look at the elected
politicians of your country that these people are truly the best and the
brightest among you? I certainly know in my country, this is not the fact. 
ZEIT: Do you regard the Corona crisis as a moment
like 9/11 where democratic values are falling apart?
Snowden: In terms of grabs for new authorities,
absolutely. It’s not just in governments this time either. It’s in terms of
companies that are developing trackers. All of these analytics companies that
last year were probably sweating in their seats, worried about being regulated
scandal after scandal about how they were tracking people’s cellphones. They
immediately started turning around after the Corona virus happened and making
sexy heat maps that they could put out on Twitter or on Facebook or the nightly
news and then sell this very same information they were afraid would be
outlawed to the varied governments, they were afraid would be outlawing them.
ZEIT: How did the virus affect your life in Moscow?
Snowden: There was a period of about two months, where
there was actually a very strict lockdown in Moscow. You could not go more than
a hundred meters from your house, except taking trash to the dumpster or going
to the nearest grocery store or the nearest pharmacy. Beyond that, you’d need a
pass from the City, you had to go to the Moscow City’s website and fill out a
form with your picture, your cellphone number and your address and your name
and biographical details. You had to submit all these very personal details to
the City government to get a permission to go to a certain place at this time. I
never did that once. 
ZEIT: Because you’ve been afraid of leaving your
house?
Snowden: Well, I do leave my house more than once a
month on average.
ZEIT: Did you fear surveillance?
Snowden: I didn’t participate, because I disagree with
it. There are degrees between advising people they can’t go out or the Chinese
model of just welding people
inside their houses. A government that does well, does not simply say: You must
do this. That’s like a parent telling a child to do something. The child asks:
Why? And the parent say: Because I told you so. That logic doesn’t work at
scale for people, except in the briefest instances where they are fearful of
some consequence. And if the advice is wrong, it can actually be more dangerous
than no advice at all. It’s very tough to tell businesses that they can’t open,
when the alternative is bankruptcy. When you tell people that they cannot go
outside, when their alternative is to fall into depression or to be unhealthy,
it might cause more harm. I prefer giving good advice: Ok, you need to wear a
mask and gloves. Here is how. Here is why. And here is the effect of these
measures. 
ZEIT ONLINE: You suffer from two severe illnesses, epilepsy
and mononucleosis glandular fever. Did you ever feel particularly threatened by
Corona? 
Snowden: Besides wearing masks and gloves and limiting
the amount of places that I went, not really. Mononucleosis glandular fever was
many years ago and I haven’t had a seizure in a long time. If there is some
place, that I don’t need to go, if I can order something instead of picking it
up in person, I’ll prefer that. The biggest impact that it has had on me is
that the conference circuit no longer really exists because I spoke at many of
these events.
ZEIT ONLINE: You have been living in Russia for seven years
now. Do you speak Russian, do you have Russian friends? 
Snowden: I’m quite comfortable in ordinary life and do
speak Russian fine. Moscow is a beautiful city. The politics of the place are
as troubled as ever but the people are fundamentally good people. As I would
say in many countries, it is never the people you have to worry about, it’s
always the government.
ZEIT ONLINE: Can you move freely or do people recognize you
a lot?
Snowden: The nice thing about the Corona virus is where
I rarely got recognized before, I never get recognized now. Corona is kind of
like a fringe benefit (laughs). Once, I was at the Tretjakow museum, with my
family who had come to visit me and so I was showing my mom one of the halls
with old religious art. And suddenly, there was a young German girl who came up
to me and said: "Mr. Snowden?" And I was like: "Yeah, you got me." She asked if
she could take a selfie with me and I said, of course, just don’t post it until
after I leave. And the nice thing was, she never posted it at all, at least I
never saw it hit the media, so she kept it for herself as a private moment. I
really appreciated that. 
ZEIT ONLINE: In your biography, you describe a moment in
2013 at the Scheremetjewo airport where the Russian Secret Service tried to
recruit you. Did that ever happen again?
Snowden: No. I refused to have any contact after that.
I know how these pitches are made and I said: Look, I am just not going to talk
to you. They didn’t make any attempts beyond that.
ZEIT: The Russian politician Alexej Nawalny has
recently been poisoned, allegedly by Russian intelligence agents. Does it feel
weird to live in a country that apparently conducts such bloody Black Op
business?
Snowden: The sad reality is that even in the
United States, targeted killings are happening frequently. It’s just the means
that’s different. Whether you are talking about killing someone with a bomb or
killing them with poison, that is still something to be condemned. I condemned
the attack on Nawalny publicly on Twitter. What’s especially chilling is not
the fact that someone is being poisoned, although that should be worthy of
condemnation, just as it should be condemned droning someone from the skies,
like the 16 year old son of the imam and alleged militant Islamist Anwar al-Awlaki in Yemen. But it’s the fact that this is the most prominent
opposition figure in Russia. 
ZEIT: What kind of reactions did you get
in Russia?
Snowden: I actually got some criticism from some
Russians when I said this online, which happens every time when I say something
in favor of Nawalny. 
ZEIT ONLINE: How do they argue? 
Snowden: They argue that he only polls at 2
percent and is just an "ultra-nationalist". But for me, it’s not about who has
the most formally polled support, particularly when someone is banned from
running in elections. The question is: who is prominent, has the platform and
the people who are listening to him? Nawalny is uniquely positioned in this
perspective. It’s a crime against all of Russia, if this person was poisoned.
There needs to be an investigation and anyone involved needs to go to jail. It
is constantly a point of shame for me to look at the way governments today are
willing to describe the political opposition as extreme, and Russia is a leader
amongst them. 
And whether they actually start poisoning someone or whether it is
simply an environment that creates a belief that a poisoning would be justified
or in the case of the United States, just the straight application of political
violence going up and shooting someone that you disagree with or thinking that
they got packs of kids in basement or the pizza kitchen or something like that…
ZEIT ONLINE: You’re speaking about the armed man
who entered a Pizza place in Washington in 2016 and fired several shots because
he believed that Hillary Clinton was holding children captive in the
restaurant. He was a follower of the QAnon ideology which is a far right conspiracy theory alleging
that cabal of Satan-worshiping
pedophiles running a global child sex-trafficking ring... 
Snowden: The creation of these environments
does not happen by mistake. It is part of an intentional political strategy
that I think we really need to work to dispel. The sad thing to me is to see,
that there are some people who actually applaud it as long as this violence
happens to people they don’t like.
ZEIT ONLINE: Have you ever been afraid that the United States will try to hunt you down in Moscow?
Snowden: There is a question between being afraid of it
or recognizing that they certainly could. And they certainly considered it. We
have articles in the newspaper in the United States from around 2013, with very
senior intelligence officials like Michael Hayden, former director of the CIA
and the NSA, talking about proposing me for a kill list. Other people discussed
anonymously how they would kill me. They would poison me on the street and then I would fall in the shower and collapse.
People constantly condemn Russia for this, because we see the cases in Russia.
We see journalists pushed off buildings or rather falling off buildings
mysteriously. We see these spades of poisonings and we see a widespread
condemnation of it, because in the West, it is costless to condemn it happening
in Russia. But we don’t see the same level of condemnation when it happens in
other countries. Yes, it must be condemned in Russia. Yes, it must be stopped,
but it must be stopped everywhere. 
ZEIT ONLINE: If someone had told you ten years ago that you
would be living in Russia and would be an enemy of the State in the US, what
would your reaction have been?
Snowden: I would have laughed. Russia would not be my
first choice.
ZEIT ONLINE: Julian Assange the founder of Wikileaks helped
you escaping to Russia. He himself is on trial in London, waiting for a
decision about the US extradition request. What will happen to him?
Snowden: What is happening to Julian Assange is
appalling and I think, the lack of support for him from many in the media is
appalling. Julian Assange is a complicated and controversial figure. There is
no question that he has radical political views and there is no question that
he has made decisions that don’t look good in hindsight.
ZEIT ONLINE: What do you mean in particular?
Snowden: The Wikileaks account was in 2016 in direct
contact with Donald Trump Jr, exchanging strategic thoughts. That kind of stuff
obviously is not what the Wikileaks mission should be about. But you can also
look at what Wikileaks was intended to do, what their mission statement was,
which was to use the information disclosed to them. And I think, there is no
question that they actually very much delivered on that goal. The very best
work that Wikileaks has ever done is covering the Iraq War Logs, the State
Department cables, the Guantanamo stuff. And this is what Assange is being
prosecuted for in the United States – and so much of the press is silent about
that because they don’t like the results of the 2016 election?
ZEIT: Would you reject information if it
came from Russian intelligence?
Snowden: There is no public indication that
I am aware of that Wikileaks knew that the Clinton mails did come from Russian
intelligence. But setting aside that, let’s say it did, let’s say DIE ZEIT or
the New York Times got an e-mail that literally said: "From Russia with
Love", signed by Vladimir Putin, and it is an astounding repository of
information, private e-mail, documents from inside the government, that reveals
something about corruption – do you publish it or not? I would argue, that the
provenience of information is less important than the accuracy of it.
Information needs to be judged on its truthfulness, its importance, rather than
provenience. If you get an e-mail from the Russian government, put that in the
story, by all means, but that doesn’t mean you should not print it.
ZEIT: Is the US government seeking for revenge against
Assange?
Snowden: Absolutely, in terms of the way, the United States is persecuting him. This is not a prosecution, this is persecution. They
are putting him in solitary isolation, maximum prison, they are treating this
guy like a terrorist. It is absolute insanity for a non-violent, clearly
political and press-associated figure. Honestly, in any reasonable country,
this extradition would be dismissed out of hand. 
ZEIT ONLINE: If you had a wish, where would you be in ten
years’ time?
Snowden: I would be back home. But the reality is, I
don’t worry so much any more about where I put my head down at night. I’m
trying to look at things on the longer view. If I can tell you one thing about
people, it’s that in the end, we will get the world we want. It will not be
easy. It will not happen wholly in our lifetimes, but if you look at the
history that we came from and the world we have today, despite all of our
problems, things are getting better. 
ZEIT: Before you left the US, you practiced martial
arts at a gym in Maryland and were even teaching. Do you still practice?
Snowden: The place that I went to is a family-style
dojo for martial arts. It’s true that I taught some classes, it was something
that I enjoyed a lot. But my life is so different now that other than
practicing on my own, it’s not something that I have done. But I still practice
once in a while.
ZEIT ONLINE: Your longtime girlfriend Lindsay Mills followed
you to Moscow and you are married now. Under the circumstances that you are
living at the moment, is it possible to start a family?
Snowden: Sure! We will see what the future holds for
us, but I can say, I’ve never been more in love and our relationship has never
been stronger.
